article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: First attested in English in the mid-15th century, the wordcaratcame from Italiancarato, which came fromGreek languageGreekkertion() meaningcarobseed (literally "small horn") and potentially fromArabic languageArabicqr().OEtymDcarat, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on PerseusWalter W. Skeat (1888),An Etymological Dictionary of the English Language(diminutive of -keras, "horn", Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseus)and was a unit of weightcarat, Oxford Dictionariesthough it was not likely used to measure gold in classical times.TheLatin languageLatinword for carat issiliqua.This common belief that carat derives from carob seeds stems from the assumption that the seeds had unusually low variability in mass.

However, one group of researchers have found that carob seeds in fact have typical variability compared to the seeds of other species.Cite journalTurnbullL. A.SantamariaL.MartorellT.RalloJ.HectorA.Seed size variability: From carob to caratsBiology Letters23397–400200617148413168618410.1098/rsbl.2006.0476

This was not the only reason. It is said that, in order to keep regional buyers and sellers of gold honest, potential customers could retrieve their own carob seeds on their way to the market, to check the tolerances of the seeds used by the merchant. If this precaution was not taken, the potential customers would be at the mercy of "2 sets of carob seeds". One set of "heavier" carob seeds would be used when buying from a customer (making the seller's gold appear to be less). Another, lighter set of carob seeds would be used when the merchant wanted to sell to a customer.citation neededNovember 2011
In the past, each country had its own carat. It was often used for weighing gold. Starting in the 1570s, it was used to measure weights of diamonds.

article.heading: Greco-Roman
article.paragraph: Thesoliduswas also a Roman weight unit. There is literary evidence that the weight of 72 coins of the type calledsolidus (coin)soliduswas exactly 1Roman pound, and that the weight of 1 soliduswas 24 siliquasiliquae. The weight of a Roman pound is generally believed to have been 327.45 g or possibly up to 5 g less. Therefore, the metric equivalent of 1siliquawas approximately 189 mg. The Greeks had a similar unit of the same value.cite journalhttp://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/brill/sho/1960/00000003/00000003/art00001GriersonPhilipThe Monetary Reforms of'Abd Al-MalikJournal of the Economic and Social History of the Orient31960241–26410.1163/156852060X000983

Gold fineness in carats comes from carats and grains of gold in a solidus of coin. One solidus = 24 carats, 1 carat = 4 grains, is preserved right up to this day.
